anchoring.anchoring_output:
The French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen was written in 1789 during the French Revolution. It was primarily drafted by the Marquis de Lafayette, with input from Thomas Jefferson and other members of the National Assembly. The declaration was influenced by Enlightenment ideals and aimed to establish fundamental rights for all citizens, including liberty, property, security, and resistance to oppression. It served as a key document in shaping modern concepts of human rights and political freedoms.

The Marquis de Lafayette, a French aristocrat and military officer, played a significant role in the drafting of the declaration. His experiences in the American Revolutionary War and his advocacy for constitutional monarchy and individual rights contributed to his involvement in the creation of the document. Lafayette's collaboration with other influential figures of the time, such as Thomas Jefferson, reflects the international impact of the declaration and its resonance with the broader principles of liberty and equality.

In summary, the French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen was primarily written by the Marquis de Lafayette, with contributions from other members of the National Assembly and external influences such as Enlightenment philosophy and international perspectives on human rights.
